items.name: Yellow Butter Cake
items.desc: Many a kid's birthday party is celebrated with a sheet-cake version of this dessert that's topped with billows of chocolate frosting and rainbow sprinkles. Yellow butter cakes often involve creaming the butter and sugar together (in modern times, this is done with an electric mixer) then adding the dry and wet ingredients, but there are also “dump” versions where all of the ingredients are thrown into a bowl and simply mixed together.

items.name: Pound Cake
items.desc: Named because it's made with a pound of each of the main ingredients (flour, butter, and sugar), this cake doesn’t rise much while baking, and the texture is very dense. Our version boasts matcha and cocoa powder, but classic recipes have nothing but vanilla extract to flavor it. Bake up one of these beauties in a loaf or Bundt pan.

items.name: Red Velvet Cake
items.desc: This is a true favorite, especially in the south. Made with either butter or oil, red velvet cake's color classically comes from the reaction of buttermilk and cocoa powder. Modern versions often achieve this hue by using red food coloring, or in the case of the raspberry velvet cake, shown here, pink.

items.name: Carrot Cake
items.desc: Leavened with baking soda and baking powder, this shortened cake uses oil as its main fat rather than butter. The addition of grated carrots makes the cake extra moist. Carrot cake is also flavored with warm spices and frosted with a rich cream cheese frosting. Pecans or walnuts are optional!

items.name: Sponge Cake
items.desc: This is a foam-style cake that has no artificial leaveners (baking powder or baking soda). It gets its volume solely from whipped eggs —either whole eggs or simply whites. This cake takes well to being soaked in a flavored syrup (try soaking with a lemon syrup and serve with a dollop of lemon curd), layered with whipped cream and smashed berries, or if baked up thin, rolled in the Christmas classic, Buche de Noel.

items.name: Genoise Cake
items.desc: Genoise is what a sponge cake is called in Italy or France. In this cake, egg yolks, whites and sugar are beaten together until mousse-like. Next, flour, and either oil or butter, are folded in. This type of sponge cake is more moist and tender than its sponge cake cousin.

items.name: Deep Fried Soft Crabs
items.desc: Prepare artichokes and soak them in fresh milk. Beat eggs and soak live crabs in them. Drain crabs and artichokes and sprinkle with flour.Deep fry crabs and artichoke.

items.name: Potato Croquettes
items.desc: Peel potatoes, boil them, and mash them into a puree with butter. Season with salt, white pepper, nutmeg, grated cheese, and an egg yolk. Form the croquettes. Pass them through flour, a beaten egg, and breadcrumbs. Fry in hot oil.

items.name: Keema Samosa
items.desc: This Samosa finds a special mention in Ramadan and is a variation, where the filling is made of minced mutton and a melange of spices and yoghurt. This samosa is sealed with flour paste and is then left for drying.

items.name: Aloo Samosa
items.desc: This is one of the most common samosas that you can enjoy as it's easily available across the country. It's crispy, flaky and the filling is something to die for in the chilled winters. With a spicy potato filling, this samosa is best enjoyed with a cup of hot tea.

items.name: Maggi Samosa
items.desc: The love for Maggi is world-known, and how about a samosa stuffed with it? Don’t be surprised, as we bring you the recipe of Maggi Samosa. The procedure for making samosa is the same, the only difference is that you must add the freshly made Maggi as the stuffing of samosas, and then deep fry it.

items.name: Chilli Cheese Samosa
items.desc: This samosa is prepared by making a mixture of cheese, boiled potatoes and green chillies. This samosa is super-delicious in taste and is baked to perfection at 200 degrees C for 15 minutes. However, this samosa is also best enjoyed as fried only.

items.name: Chocolate Samosa
items.desc: This sweet samosa is made by stuffing it with a mixture of melted chocolate and dry fruits and then sealing it. Further, it's deep-fried and then dipped in thick sugar syrup.

items.name: Rice stick noodles
items.desc: Rice stick noodles are flat and translucent and can be either wide or slender. They are not difficult to spot and they are usually sold in bundles.

items.name: Egg noodles
items.desc: One of the most common noodles used in Asian cuisine, these noodles are also known as Chinese egg noodles or E-fu noodles.

items.name: Hokkien noodles
items.desc: Thick in texture and yellow in colour, these noodles are prepared from egg and wheat flour.

items.name: creamy pasta with chilli
items.desc: soft, saucy and creamy pasta with extra sauce and chilli
